query: What is the current best score on Kaggle Santa 2025 leaderboard and what techniques are top teams using to achieve scores below 70?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text: 71.1914 (team terry_u16) is the leading score on the Santa 2025 leaderboard as of 20 Jan 2026 ([kaggle.com](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025/leaderboard)); top teams push scores below 70 by using crystallography‑inspired lattice packing—combining multiple lattice arrangements and other heuristic optimization techniques instead of reinforcement‑learning methods ([kaggle.com](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025/discussion/665669), [medium.com](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97)).

results.title: Kaggle Santa 2025: Why “Reinforcement Learning” is Failing
results.text:

![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*dmbNkD5D-u45r44go_cf0g.png)
# Kaggle Santa 2025: Why “Reinforcement Learning” is Failing
[
![Himanshu Dhiman](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*3jyWFYIYAox5D7cqT7gIRA.jpeg)
](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--087f3f04fa97---------------------------------------)
[Himanshu Dhiman](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/?source=post_page---byline--087f3f04fa97---------------------------------------)
3 min read
·Dec 21, 2025
[
](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/vote/p/087f3f04fa97&operation=register&redirect=https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97&user=Himanshu+Dhiman&userId=288bb1baa8d2&source=---header_actions--087f3f04fa97---------------------clap_footer------------------)
--
[](https://medium.com/m/signin?actionUrl=https://medium.com/_/bookmark/p/087f3f04fa97&operation=register&redirect=https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97&source=---header_actions--087f3f04fa97---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)
Listen
Share
Press enter or click to view image in full size
![]()
Every December, Kaggle drops a “Santa” competition that ruins the holidays for thousands of data scientists. We expect a fun puzzle. We get a nightmare of Combinatorial Optimization.
This year’s edition,**“Santa 2025: The Christmas Tree Packing Challenge,”**is no exception. The goal? Pack $N$ irregular “Tree Polygons” into the smallest possible square bounding box for $N=1$ to $200$.
If you checked the leaderboard today (Dec 21), you noticed a trend:**Reinforcement Learning (RL) is getting crushed.**
Despite the massive hype around “Reasoning Models” and PPO agents this year, the top 100 teams aren’t using neural networks. They are using 1980s physics simulations. Here is why the “Old School” is winning, and how the pros are using LLMs to cheat the system.
## The Problem: Why RL Hates “Packing”
On paper, this looks like a game.*Place a tree, check for overlap, repeat.*Perfect for a DQN agent, right?
Wrong. The geometry kills the gradient.
1. **Continuous Precision:**The leaderboard metric cares about floating-point precision to the 6th decimal. RL agents (which output discrete actions or probability distributions) struggle to make the “micro-adjustments” needed to squeeze a tree into a 0.001mm gap.
2. **The “Collision” Cliff:**In packing, a move is either valid (reward = 1) or it overlaps by a pixel (reward = -100). This sparse, binary feedback loop makes it nearly impossible for an agent to “learn” a gradient. It doesn’t know*how*to fix the overlap, just that it failed.## The Solution: Simulated Annealing (on Steroids)
The “Secret Sauce” currently dominating the leaderboard is**Simulated Annealing (SA)**combined with**Lattice Generation**.
Instead of training a model to*predict*the position, teams are writing physics engines that*shake*the box.
* **High Temperature:**Randomly spin and throw trees into the box (Explorer Phase).
* **Low Temperature:**Jiggle the trees by microscopic amounts to resolve collisions (Exploiter Phase).
The best solutions right now use a “Hybrid” strategy:
* **N < 58:**Use Simulated Annealing to find unstructured, chaotic packings.
* **N > 58:**Switch to “Crystalline Packing” (regular geometric lattices) which is mathematically superior for large numbers.## The Twist: How LLMs are Actually Helping
If RL is dead, where is the AI?
Top competitors aren’t using LLMs to*solve*the puzzle; they are using LLMs to**write the solver**.
Python is too slow for 10 billion annealing steps. The meta this year is to prompt Gemini 3 or Claude to:
“Rewrite this Python overlap-check function in Rust/C++ with AVX2 vectorization.”
We are seeing “Hybrid” workflows where the**Human**defines the heuristics, the**LLM**writes the highly optimized C++ kernels, and**Simulated Annealing**does the heavy lifting.
## The Starter Code: A Simple Annealer
If you want to jump in before the January deadline, don’t start with PyTorch. Start here.
Here is a conceptual snippet for a “Perturbation” mover —the heart of any good annealing solution.
```
import numpy as np
import math
def anneal(layout, max\_temps=10000):
# layout: Array of [x, y, rotation] for N trees
current\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
temperature = 1.0
cooling\_rate = 0.9995
for i in range(max\_temps):
# 1. Propose a Move (The "Shake")
# We only move ONE tree slightly to save compute
idx = np.random.randint(0, len(layout))
original\_pos = layout[idx].copy()
# Perturb: Move x/y by small amount, rotate slightly
layout[idx][0] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][1] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][2] += np.random.normal(0, temperature \* 10) # Rotate
# 2. Check Constraints (The "Wall")
if check\_overlap(layout):
# Revert immediately if invalid
layout[idx] = original\_pos
continue
# 3. Acceptance Criteria (Metropolis-Hastings)
new\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
delta = new\_score - current\_score
# If better, accept. If worse, accept with prob based on Temp.
if delta < 0 or math.exp(-delta / temperature) > np.random.rand():
current\_score = new\_score
else:
layout[idx] = original\_pos # Revert
# Cool down
temperature \*= cooling\_rate
return layout, current\_score
# Pro Tip: Ask an LLM to convert ''check\_overlap'' to Cython for 100x speed.
```
The competition ends**January 30, 2026**. You have 40 days. Put down the Neural Network and pick up a physics textbook.
*(****Discussion:****Are you using a Lattice approach or pure Annealing for N=200? Let’s discuss strategy in the comments!)*
[
![Himanshu Dhiman](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:96:96/1*3jyWFYIYAox5D7cqT7gIRA.jpeg)

# Kaggle Progression System

Kaggle's Progression System uses performance tiers to track your growth as a data scientist on Kaggle. Along the way, you’ll earn medals for your achievements and compete for data science glory on live leaderboards.

![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/tier-animation-transparent.gif)

## Categories of Expertise

The Progression System is designed around four Kaggle categories of data science expertise: Competitions, Notebooks, Datasets, and Discussion. Advancement through performance tiers is done independently within each category of expertise.

## Performance Tiers

Within each category of expertise, there are five performance tiers that can be achieved in accordance with the quality and quantity of work you produce: Novice, Contributor, Expert, Master, and Grandmaster.

For example, you could be a Competitions Master, a Datasets Expert, a Notebooks Grandmaster, and a Discussion Expert:

![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/tiers-example.png)

The highest tier you have achieved in any of the categories of expertise will be displayed on your profile and under your avatar across the site. Tiers are awarded on the basis of medals earned in each category.

![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/tiers/novice.svg)

### Novice

You’ve joined the community.

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ Register!

![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/tiers/contributor.svg)

### Contributor

You’ve completed your profile, engaged with the community, and fully explored Kaggle’s platform.

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ Run 1 notebook or script

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ Make 1 competition submission

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ Make 1 comment

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ Give 1 upvote

![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/tiers/expert.svg)

### Expert

You’ve completed a significant body of work on Kaggle in one or more categories of expertise. Once you’ve reached the expert tier for a category, you will be entered into the site wide Kaggle Ranking for that category.

###### Competitions

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-bronze.svg)2 bronze medals

###### Datasets

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-bronze.svg)3 bronze medals

###### Notebooks

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-bronze.svg)5 bronze medals

###### Discussion

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-bronze.svg)50 bronze medals

![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/tiers/master.svg)

### Master

You’ve demonstrated excellence in one or more categories of expertise on Kaggle to reach this prestigious tier. Masters in the Competitions category are eligible for exclusive Master-Only competitions.

###### Competitions

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)1 gold medal

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-silver.svg)2 silver medals

###### Datasets

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)1 gold medal

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-silver.svg)4 silver medals

###### Notebooks

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-silver.svg)10 silver medals

###### Discussion

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-silver.svg)50 silver medals

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ 200 medals in total

![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/tiers/grandmaster.svg)

### Grandmaster

You’ve consistently demonstrated outstanding performance in one or more categories of expertise on Kaggle to reach this pinnacle tier. You’re the best of the best.

###### Competitions

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)5 gold medals

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)Solo gold medal

###### Datasets

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)5 gold medals

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-silver.svg)5 silver medals

###### Notebooks

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)15 gold medals

###### Discussion

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)50 gold medals

_check\_box\_outline\_blank_ 500 medals in total

## Medals

To reward your best work

Medals are a standardized way of recognizing and rewarding excellent pieces of work across the categories of expertise on Kaggle. Each medal is awarded for a single accomplishment: a great competition result, a popular notebook, a useful dataset or an insightful comment.

## Competition Medals

Competition medals are awarded for top competition results. The number of medals awarded per competition varies depending on the size of the competition. Percentage calculations are rounded down. For example, a competition with 9 teams will not award any gold medals. Note that Community, Playground, and Getting Started competitions typically do not award medals.

|  | 0-99 Teams | 100-249 Teams | 250-999 Teams | 1000+ Teams |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-bronze.svg)Bronze | Top 40% | Top 40% | Top 100 | Top 10% |
| ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-silver.svg)Silver | Top 20% | Top 20% | Top 50 | Top 5% |
| ![](https://www.kaggle.com/static/images/medals/reflection-gold.svg)Gold | Top 10% | Top 10 | Top 10 + 0.2%\* | Top 10 + 0.2%\* |

\\* (Top 10 + 0.2%) means that an extra gold medal will be awarded for every 500 additional teams in the competition. For example, a competition with 500 teams will award gold medals to the top 11 teams and a competition with 5000 teams will award gold medals to the top 20 teams.

## Dataset Medals

Dataset Medals are awarded to popular public datasets published to the site, as measured by number of upvotes. Not all upvotes count towards medals: self-votes and votes by novices are excluded from medal calculation.

In this re-defined optimization problem, help Santa fit Christmas tree toys into the smallest (2-dimension) parcel size possible so that he can efficiently mail these stocking stuffers around the globe. Santa needs the dimensions of the smallest possible square box that fits shipments of between 1-200 trees.

## Repository files navigation
# Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge V1
[](#santa-2025---christmas-tree-packing-challenge-v1)
This repository contains my approach for the[Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025)on Kaggle.
## Overview
[](#overview)
The objective of this challenge is to optimally pack rotatable Christmas trees (polygonal shapes) into the smallest possible square, minimizing the bounding box area for each value of N (number of trees from 1 to 200). The final solution is evaluated by an ensemble score that combines all cases.
**Notebook Link**:[Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge V1](https://www.kaggle.com/code/adityapawar327/santa-2025-christmas-tree-packing-challenge-v1)
**Public Score**: 85.92
## Table of Contents
[](#table-of-contents)
* Library Imports and Environment Setup
* Global Configuration and Precision Settings
* ChristmasTree Class Definition
* Utility Functions (Scoring/Collision)
* Simulated Annealing Algorithm (N < 20)
* Grid Search Algorithm (N >= 20)
* Hybrid & Ensemble Solvers
* Main Computation Loop (N = 1 to 200)
* Submission Formatting and Export
## Methodology
[](#methodology)
* **Small N (< 20):**Uses Simulated Annealing for efficient search in small configuration spaces.
* **Large N (>= 20):**Uses a tailored Grid Search for tractable solution space exploration.
* **Hybrid/Ensemble:**Runs multiple seeds and chooses the best solution for each N.
* **Collision Detection:**Employs Shapely geometry operations to prevent tree overlap.
* **Performance:**Code leverages parallelization (`ProcessPoolExecutor`) and high-precision (Decimal) arithmetic.
## Usage
[](#usage)
1. Install dependencies:
* `shapely`,`numpy`,`pandas`,`matplotlib`,`tqdm`
* Run the notebook or script sequentially to output results and save a`submission.csv`.
* Check the score on important N cases (e.g., 1, 10, 25, 50, 100, 150, 200).
## Output
[](#output)
* The notebook prints key logs during computation.
* A`submission.csv`is generated with columns:`id`,`x`,`y`,`deg`(example row:`001\_0, s-9.146226, s-0.12832, s-224.999647`).
